Massachusetts General Laws chapter 218,.proposition: This Court has jurisdiction over this matter pursuant to Massachusetts General Laws chapter 218, § 19.

G.L. c. 186, \u00a7 14.proposition: Massachusetts law, specifically G.L. c. 186, § 14, implies in every lease agreement a covenant of quiet enjoyment, which protects tenants from substantial interference with their use and enjoyment of rented premises.

*Dartmouth v. Silva*, 325 Mass. 401 (195.proposition: Under Massachusetts case law, landlords are liable for breaches of the covenant of quiet enjoyment even when caused by other tenants, so long as the landlord fails to take reasonable actions to address the interference.
*Dartmouth v. Silva*, 325 Mass. 401 (195.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a town’s suit to abate a public nuisance caused by defendants obstructing and diverting a natural watercourse, leading to flooding of public ways. It does not involve landlord‑tenant law, covenants of quiet enjoyment, or landlord liability for interference caused by other tenants. Because the case neither discusses nor implies rules about quiet enjoyment or landlord obligations to address tenant-caused interference, it does not support the claimed proposition.
*Dartmouth v. Silva*, 325 Mass. 401 (195.relevant_excerpt: “The plaintiff grounds its right to relief on the existence of a nuisance. We construe the findings of the master as establishing that the brook which ran through the land of the defendants was a natural watercourse… The obstruction of a watercourse so as to cause the water to flow over a highway is a public nuisance.… A town is under a duty to keep its ways in repair and is liable to travellers injured by reason of a breach of that duty.”

*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.proposition: Under Massachusetts case law, landlords are liable for breaches of the covenant of quiet enjoyment even when caused by other tenants, so long as the landlord fails to take reasonable actions to address the interference.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.support_reasoning: The court holds that landlords can be liable for breach of quiet enjoyment where disturbances are caused by another tenant (the lounge) and the landlord fails to exercise control to abate the problem. It explicitly rejects a strict non-liability rule for tenant-on-tenant interference and emphasizes that liability arises when the interference is the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did or failed to do and where the landlord had the right and ability to control the objectionable conditions.
*Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714 (19.relevant_excerpt: “Because the disturbing condition was the natural and probable consequence of the landlords’ permitting the lounge to operate where it did and because the landlords could control the actions at the lounge, they should not be entitled to collect rent for residential premises which were not reasonably habitable. Tenants such as these should not be left only with a claim against the proprietors of the noisome lounge…. [W]e decline to perpetuate [the] distinction [between nonfeasance and malfeasance] where the landlord creates a situation and has the right to control the objectionable conditions.”
